docs.lead_paragraph: Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas, which treated the only Ebola patient to die in the United States, will pay his relatives an undisclosed sum and create a charitable foundation in his name, the family’s lawyer said Wednesday.

headline.main: Texas: Ebola Victim’s Family to Be Paid by Hospital
headline.print_headline: Texas: Ebola Victim’s Family to Be Paid by Hospital

docs.abstract: Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas, which treated Ebola patient Thomas Eric Duncan, has agreed to financial settlement with his family and creation of charitable foundation in his name; relatives had been critical of care Duncan received, saying his death was partly due to his race and lack of insurance.
docs.snippet: Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas, which treated the only Ebola patient to die in the United States, will pay his relatives an undisclosed sum and create a charitable foundation in his name, the family’s lawyer said Wednesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans have plans to transform Medicare and Medicaid and to cut taxes for high earners, measures once out of reach with Democrats controlling the Senate.

headline.main: In Control, Republican Lawmakers See Budget as Way to Push Agenda
headline.print_headline: In Control, Republican Lawmakers See Budget as Way to Push Agenda

docs.abstract: Congressional Republicans, now in control, have plans to overhaul Medicare, transform Medicaid, and cut highest tax rates through budget process, measures once out of reach with Democrats controlling Senate; new Senate GOP majority will decide how far to press small-government vision.
docs.snippet: Congressional Republicans have plans to transform Medicare and Medicaid and to cut taxes for high earners, measures once out of reach with Democrats controlling the Senate.

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Wednesday delayed plans to handle a challenge to the Obama administration's health care law because the Supreme Court is stepping into a separate case covering the same legal ground.

docs.lead_paragraph: The technology glitches may be a thing of the past. But people shopping online for health insurance plans under U.S. President Barack Obama's healthcare law may encounter a new set of problems early next year, one of them being unexpected new costs.
